title: How to write a descriptive paragraph about a room - Quora

response.answer_text: Shay Hill’s answer was pretty great. I just want to remind you not to infodump the reader. Tell what is necessary for the reader to understand whatever it is they need to understand and nothing more. For example… If the owner of the room was missing and the purpose of the scene was to find clues about him, then you could do a little longer piece focusing on the details that make the room his. ”The bedroom was spotless. Even though dust had began to settle on the tabletops, the room was clean. Nothing was out of place; the books all neatly side by side in alphabetical order on the shelf, the folded clothes at the end of the made queen-sized bed, and the huge, white fur carpet on the floor that looked like it had never been stepped on. The window let the room soak in sunlight, revealing the dust particles floating peacefully in the air. The detective’s nose wrinkled as he stepped further in. Something sharp lingered in the air; maybe the smell of a window cleaner.” (So now we know the guy is super tidy and that he reads. These two facts could be the super important clue that at the end help the detective find him.) Usually it sounds nice if the description is inserted into action. Reveal something about the character through the room and their thoughts and actions, like: ”She closed the door behind her, tossed the clothes off her unmade bed and climbed in, careful not to accidentally smack the dirty cups off her nightstand. Leaning over the edge of the bed, she grabbed the laptop from underneath her bed and pulled it on her lap. As she waited for Skype to open, she looked around at her room. She still hadn’t cleaned up the desk like her mom had told her to, or the floors, or her closet, or the shelf… Oh well. It could wait until she was done talking with Matt — but to be honest, it could take a while. Maybe it could wait until tomorrow.” (This is more showing than telling, and you usually want to go for showing. You immediately get the idea that her room is messy and that she doesn’t really care. Like a regular teenager. Two birds with one stone. It also doesn’t feel like the story stops to give the reader a bunch of information. This is personally the style I’d go with.) Or if the room does not matter all that much, you can do just a few words. Usually just a few words is enough. For example: ”He passed the messy lounge and walked into the kitchen, dodging trays, bowls of food and waitresses as he made his way towards the back door.” (You know based on this that it’s a restaurant/cafe/hotel kitchen, so the reader immediately pictures that instead of a home kitchen.) ”She bit back tears as she rushed into the tiny bathroom on the second floor. She locked the door, drew in a deep breath — and lost control. Her friend banged on the door, demanding to know what was going on, but she simply leaned against the sink and cried.” (It’s only important to the scene that she’s locked herself into a bathroom to cry. It doesn’t matter what the bathroom looks like.) ”He stopped at the door and took in the ballroom; the flyers on the walls begging guests to donate, the hundreds of people all dressed in the fanciest dresses and suits, and the huge chandelier that hung from the ceiling almost ten meters above the guests’ heads.” (We get the idea from just these three things.) These are bad examples and only a few but I hope that’s helpful!

Keep in mind who's speaking (even if the speaker is the narrator) and who's being spoken to (even if the listener is the reader). Share the details that make sense in that relationship. Depending on the relationship of the speaker to the listener, the description could consist of physical details;Purple curtains shaded small windows. how the room makes a particular character feel;The small windows and dim corners made Nancy uneasy. what the room says about the person who inhabits it;The inhabitant had never found a reason to update the purple curtains and gold upholstery. what the room is missing;The old man had been sleeping here, but there was no bed, no chair, and very little light. what the condition of the room reveals;Someone was obviously proud of his trophy collection. what the room is used for; orThe Johnson boys had been bringing girls here since 8th grade. generalities.It was an unremarkable room. Start from one of these. Don't let your narrator get out of voice. Be careful with generalities. Keep your listener’s perspective in mind.
